elements.content: We prepared a vanadium heptacyanomolybdate-based magnet, VII 2[MoIII(CN)7]·(pyrimidine)2·4.5H2O (VMo), with a Curie temperature (T C) of 110 K, which is the highest T C value in [MoIII(CN)7]-based magnets. Additionally, MnII 2[MoIII(CN)7]·(pyrimidine)2·2H2O (MnMo) of a monoclinic structure (P21/n) with T C = 47 K was prepared to confirm the crystal structure of VMo.
elements.clean_text: We prepared a vanadium heptacyanomolybdate-based magnet, VII 2[MoIII(CN)7]⋅(pyrimidine)2⋅4.5H2O (VMo), with a Curie temperature (T C) of 110 K, which is the highest T C value in [MoIII(CN)7]-based magnets. Additionally, MnII 2[MoIII(CN)7]⋅(pyrimidine)2⋅2H2O (MnMo) of a monoclinic structure (P21/n) with T C = 47 K was prepared to confirm the crystal structure of VMo.

elements.content: We prepared a vanadium heptacyanomolybdate-based magnet, VII 2[MoIII(CN)7]·(pyrimidine)2·4.5H2O (VMo), with a Curie temperature (T C) of 110 K, which is the highest T C value in [MoIII(CN)7]-based magnets. Additionally, MnII 2[MoIII(CN)7]·2pyrimidine·2H2O (MnMo) of a monoclinic structure (P21/n) with T C = 47 K was prepared to confirm the crystal structure of VMo.
elements.clean_text: We prepared a vanadium heptacyanomolybdate-based magnet, VII 2[MoIII(CN)7]⋅(pyrimidine)2⋅4.5H2O (VMo), with a Curie temperature (T C) of 110 K, which is the highest T C value in [MoIII(CN)7]-based magnets. Additionally, MnII 2[MoIII(CN)7]⋅2pyrimidine⋅2H2O (MnMo) of a monoclinic structure (P21/n) with T C = 47 K was prepared to confirm the crystal structure of VMo.

elements.content: In molecule-based magnets, preparing compounds with a high Curie temperature (T C) is a challenging issue. In cyano-bridged metal assemblies, high T C values have been reported using a VII-containing system. Recently, octacyanometalate [M(CN)8] (M = Mo, W, Nb)-based magnets have been aggressively studied because of their high T C and functionalities such as photomagnetism and chemically sensitive magnetism. Heptacyanometalate [Mo(CN)7]-based magnets have also attracted attention because of their high coordination numbers around the metal ions and various coordination geometries, e.g., pentagonal bipyramid (D 5h ), monocapped octahedron (C 3v ), and capped trigonal prism (C 2v ). In addition, heptacyanomolybdate has a large magnetic anisotropy, which hexacyanometalate and octacyanometalate lack. However, because of handling difficulties, heptacyanometalate-based magnets are not as well researched. Some heptacyanomolybdate-based magnets, including Mn2[Mo(CN)7]·nH2O and [Mn(N,N-dimethylalaninolH)]2Mn[Mo(CN)7]2·nH2O, have been reported. Although the combination of VII and heptacyanomolybdate has the potential of realizing high-T C molecular magnets, a VII[Mo(CN)7]-based magnet has yet to be reported. Herein we report a VII[Mo(CN)7]-based ferrimagnet, VII 2[MoIII(CN)7]·(pyrimidine)2·4.5H2O (VMo), which has a high Curie temperature of 110 K. In addition, to confirm the crystal structure of VMo, MnII 2[MoIII(CN)7]·(pyrimidine)2·2H2O (MnMo) (T C = 47 K) was synthesized.
elements.clean_text: In molecule-based magnets, preparing compounds with a high Curie temperature (T C) is a challenging issue. In cyano-bridged metal assemblies, high T C values have been reported using a VII-containing system. Recently, octacyanometalate [M(CN)8] (M = Mo, W, Nb)-based magnets have been aggressively studied because of their high T C and functionalities such as photomagnetism and chemically sensitive magnetism. Heptacyanometalate [Mo(CN)7]-based magnets have also attracted attention because of their high coordination numbers around the metal ions and various coordination geometries, e.g., pentagonal bipyramid (D 5h ), monocapped octahedron (C 3v ), and capped trigonal prism (C 2v ). In addition, heptacyanomolybdate has a large magnetic anisotropy, which hexacyanometalate and octacyanometalate lack. However, because of handling difficulties, heptacyanometalate-based magnets are not as well researched. Some heptacyanomolybdate-based magnets, including Mn2[Mo(CN)7]⋅nH2O and [Mn(N,N-dimethylalaninolH)]2Mn[Mo(CN)7]2⋅nH2O, have been reported. Although the combination of VII and heptacyanomolybdate has the potential of realizing high-T C molecular magnets, a VII[Mo(CN)7]-based magnet has yet to be reported. Herein we report a VII[Mo(CN)7]-based ferrimagnet, VII 2[MoIII(CN)7]⋅(pyrimidine)2⋅4.5H2O (VMo), which has a high Curie temperature of 110 K. In addition, to confirm the crystal structure of VMo, MnII 2[MoIII(CN)7]⋅(pyrimidine)2⋅2H2O (MnMo) (T C = 47 K) was synthesized.

elements.content: The powder form of VMo was obtained by adding 2.5 mL of a deoxygenated aqueous solution of K4[Mo(CN)7]·2H2O (5 × 10−2 mol dm−3) to 2.5 mL of a mixed deoxygenated aqueous solution of (NH4)2V(SO4)2·6H2O (1 × 10−1 mol dm−3) and pyrimidine (2 mol dm−3) under an argon atmosphere. The purplish-black precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and then dried in argon. The IR spectrum displayed a CN stretching peak at 2074 cm−1. Our attempts to prepare a single crystal were unsuccessful. Elemental analyses by the standard microanalytical method, inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy, and ion chromatography analysis confirmed that the formula was VII 2[MoIII(CN)7]·(pyrimidine)2·4.5H2O with a small amount of impurity of 0.08K2SO4. Calcd: V, 16.4; Mo, 15.5; C, 29.0; H, 2.8; N, 24.8. Found: V, 16.4; Mo, 15.2; C, 29.2; H, 2.8; N, 24.6. To confirm the crystal structure of the powder form of VMo, a single crystal of MnMo was prepared. The formula was MnII 2[MoIII(CN)7]·(pyrimidine)2·2H2O. Calcd: Mn, 18.8; Mo, 16.4; C, 30.8; H, 2.1; N, 26.4. Found: Mn, 18.7; Mo, 16.6; C, 30.5; H, 2.4; N, 26.3.
elements.clean_text: The powder form of VMo was obtained by adding 2.5 mL of a deoxygenated aqueous solution of K4[Mo(CN)7]⋅2H2O (5 × 10-2 mol dm-3) to 2.5 mL of a mixed deoxygenated aqueous solution of (NH4)2V(SO4)2⋅6H2O (1 × 10-1 mol dm-3) and pyrimidine (2 mol dm-3) under an argon atmosphere. The purplish-black precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and then dried in argon. The IR spectrum displayed a CN stretching peak at 2074 cm-1. Our attempts to prepare a single crystal were unsuccessful. Elemental analyses by the standard microanalytical method, inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy, and ion chromatography analysis confirmed that the formula was VII 2[MoIII(CN)7]⋅(pyrimidine)2⋅4.5H2O with a small amount of impurity of 0.08K2SO4. Calcd: V, 16.4; Mo, 15.5; C, 29.0; H, 2.8; N, 24.8. Found: V, 16.4; Mo, 15.2; C, 29.2; H, 2.8; N, 24.6. To confirm the crystal structure of the powder form of VMo, a single crystal of MnMo was prepared. The formula was MnII 2[MoIII(CN)7]⋅(pyrimidine)2⋅2H2O. Calcd: Mn, 18.8; Mo, 16.4; C, 30.8; H, 2.1; N, 26.4. Found: Mn, 18.7; Mo, 16.6; C, 30.5; H, 2.4; N, 26.3.

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of VMo displayed broad peaks around 19, 37, and 54° (Figure a, top). To determine the crystal structure, the XRD pattern of VMo was compared to the single-crystal X-ray analysis data of MnMo. Single-crystal X-ray analysis of MnMo indicated that this compound belonged to the monoclinic structure of space group P21/n [a = 7.20778(13) Å, b = 15.7128(3) Å, c = 18.1688(3) Å, β = 95.0877(7)°, and Z = 4]. The coordination geometries of Mn (Mn1, Mn2, and Mn3) and Mo were near to an octahedron (O h ) and near to a capped octahedron (C 3v ), respectively. The seven CN ligands of [Mo(CN)7]4− were bridged to three Mn1, two Mn2, and two Mn3. The four equatorial positions of Mn1 were occupied by three N atoms of [Mo(CN)7] and one O atom of a water ligand, while the apical positions were occupied by two N atoms from pyrimidine molecules. Mn2 was coordinated by four cyanide N atoms and two N atoms from pyrimidine. Mn3 was coordinated by four cyanide N atoms and two O atoms from the water ligands (Figure b). Figure c shows the crystal structure of MnMo. [MoIII(CN)7]4− and MnII formed a three-dimensional (3D) cyano-bridged network. The middle and bottom XRD patterns of Figure a show the simulated XRD pattern and the experimental powder XRD pattern of the powder-form MnMo, respectively. The observed XRD pattern of VMo and the calculated pattern of MnMo agree well, suggesting that the crystal structure of VMo is same as the 3D structure of MnMo.
elements.clean_text: The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of VMo displayed broad peaks around 19, 37, and 54° (Figure a, top). To determine the crystal structure, the XRD pattern of VMo was compared to the single-crystal X-ray analysis data of MnMo. Single-crystal X-ray analysis of MnMo indicated that this compound belonged to the monoclinic structure of space group P21/n [a = 7.20778(13) Å, b = 15.7128(3) Å, c = 18.1688(3) Å, β = 95.0877(7)°, and Z = 4]. The coordination geometries of Mn (Mn1, Mn2, and Mn3) and Mo were near to an octahedron (O  h ) and near to a capped octahedron (C 3v ), respectively. The seven CN ligands of [Mo(CN)7]4- were bridged to three Mn1, two Mn2, and two Mn3. The four equatorial positions of Mn1 were occupied by three N atoms of [Mo(CN)7] and one O atom of a water ligand, while the apical positions were occupied by two N atoms from pyrimidine molecules. Mn2 was coordinated by four cyanide N atoms and two N atoms from pyrimidine. Mn3 was coordinated by four cyanide N atoms and two O atoms from the water ligands (Figure b). Figure c shows the crystal structure of MnMo. [MoIII(CN)7]4- and MnII formed a three-dimensional (3D) cyano-bridged network. The middle and bottom XRD patterns of Figure a show the simulated XRD pattern and the experimental powder XRD pattern of the powder-form MnMo, respectively. The observed XRD pattern of VMo and the calculated pattern of MnMo agree well, suggesting that the crystal structure of VMo is same as the 3D structure of MnMo.

elements.content: (a) Powder XRD pattern of VMo (top), simulated diffraction pattern and intensities of the Bragg reflections based on the crystal structure of MnMo (middle; line and sticks), and the powder XRD pattern of powder-form MnMo (bottom). The peaks of a Cu sample holder are omitted for clarity. (b) Coordination environments around Mo and Mn. (c) Crystal structure of the 3D MnII−MoIII framework. H atoms are omitted for clarity. Blue, red, gray, light-blue, and light-green balls represent Mo, Mn, C, N, and O, respectively. Dark and light hexagons represent bidentate and monodentate pyrimidines, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Powder XRD pattern of VMo (top), simulated diffraction pattern and intensities of the Bragg reflections based on the crystal structure of MnMo (middle; line and sticks), and the powder XRD pattern of powder-form MnMo (bottom). The peaks of a Cu sample holder are omitted for clarity. (b) Coordination environments around Mo and Mn. (c) Crystal structure of the 3D MnII-MoIII framework. H atoms are omitted for clarity. Blue, red, gray, light-blue, and light-green balls represent Mo, Mn, C, N, and O, respectively. Dark and light hexagons represent bidentate and monodentate pyrimidines, respectively.

elements.content: The value of the product of the molar magnetic susceptibility (χM) and temperature, χM T, of VMo was 3.9 cm3 K mol−1 at room temperature (Figure S3 in the ), which corresponds to the spin-only value of 4.1 cm3 K mol−1 for MoIII (S = 1/2) and 2VII (S = 3/2). Figure shows the magnetization versus temperature plots of VMo. In the field-cooled magnetization (FCM) curve at 10 Oe, spontaneous magnetization appeared at T C = 110 K. The magnetization versus external magnetic field plots at 2 K showed that the M S value was 3.0 μB, while the magnetic hysteresis loop had a coercive field (H c) of 300 Oe at 2 K (Figure b,c). The magnetic properties of MnMo, which is a sample composed of numerous single crystals, exhibited ferrimagnetism with T C = 47 K, M S = 9.0 μB, and H c = 60 Oe at 2 K. The high T C of VMo is likely due to (i) the diffuse 4d orbitals of Mo, which enable an effective superexchange interaction through the cyano groups, and (ii) the high-energy 3d orbitals of V, which lead to a good energy match with the magnetic orbital of [Mo(CN)7]4−.

Figure  shows the magnetization versus temperature plots of VMo. In the field-cooled magnetization (FCM) curve at 10 Oe, spontaneous magnetization appeared at T C = 110 K. The magnetization versus external magnetic field plots at 2 K showed that the M S value was 3.0 μB, while the magnetic hysteresis loop had a coercive field (H c) of 300 Oe at 2 K (Figure b,c). The magnetic properties of MnMo, which is a sample composed of numerous single crystals, exhibited ferrimagnetism with T C = 47 K, M S = 9.0 μB, and H c = 60 Oe at 2 K. The high T C of VMo is likely due to (i) the diffuse 4d orbitals of Mo, which enable an effective superexchange interaction through the cyano groups, and (ii) the high-energy 3d orbitals of V, which lead to a good energy match with the magnetic orbital of [Mo(CN)7]4-.

elements.content: Magnetic properties of VMo (filled circles) and MnMo (open circles). (a) FCM versus temperature plots in an external magnetic field of 10 G. (b) Saturation magnetization curves at 2 K. (c) Magnetic hysteresis loops at 2 K.
elements.clean_text: 2  Magnetic properties of VMo (filled circles) and MnMo (open circles). (a) FCM versus temperature plots in an external magnetic field of 10 G. (b) Saturation magnetization curves at 2 K. (c) Magnetic hysteresis loops at 2 K.

elements.content: In conclusion, we prepared VII 2[MoIII(CN)7]·(pyrimidine)2·4.5H2O, a heptacyanomolybdate-based ferrimagnet with a high Curie temperature of 110 K. The observed T C is the highest value among reported heptacyanomolybdate-based magnets. We believe that a higher T C will be realized in [MoIII(CN)7]-based magnets by controlling the coordination geometries of V and Mo and by selecting the appropriate organic ligand.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we prepared VII 2[MoIII(CN)7]⋅(pyrimidine)2⋅4.5H2O, a heptacyanomolybdate-based ferrimagnet with a high Curie temperature of 110 K. The observed T C is the highest value among reported heptacyanomolybdate-based magnets. We believe that a higher T C will be realized in [MoIII(CN)7]-based magnets by controlling the coordination geometries of V and Mo and by selecting the appropriate organic ligand.

elements.content: Instrumentation, single-crystal X-ray structural analysis for MnMo, χM T−T plots of VMo, and a crystallographic information data file in CIF format for MnMo. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Instrumentation, single-crystal X-ray structural analysis for MnMo, χM T-T plots of VMo, and a crystallographic information data file in CIF format for MnMo. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Reacting a deoxygenated aqueous solution of K4[Mo(CN)7]·2H2O (5 × 10−3 mol dm−3) with a deoxygenated aqueous solution of Mn(NO3)2·6H2O (1 × 10−2 mol dm−3) containing pyrimidine (2 × 10−1 mol dm−3) in an H-shaped tube under an argon atmosphere gave a green-brown single crystal of MnMo. The IR spectrum had a CN stretching peak at 2084 cm−1.
elements.clean_text:
References

Reacting a deoxygenated aqueous solution of K4[Mo(CN)7]⋅2H2O (5 × 10-3 mol dm-3) with a deoxygenated aqueous solution of Mn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1 × 10-2 mol dm-3) containing pyrimidine (2 × 10-1 mol dm-3) in an H-shaped tube under an argon atmosphere gave a green-brown single crystal of MnMo. The IR spectrum had a CN stretching peak at 2084 cm-1.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis of MnMo indicated that this compound belonged to the monoclinic structure of space group P21/n [a = 7.20778(13) Å, b = 15.7128(3) Å, c = 18.1688(3) Å, β = 95.0877(7)°, and Z = 4]. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 to R1 (wR2) = 0.0196 (0.0631) using 4365 reflections with F 2 > 2.0σ(F 2) (Table S1 in the ). The non-H atoms were anisotropically refined. The H atoms of pyrimidine and water were refined isotropically. The asymmetric unit consisted of a [Mo(CN)7]4− anion, a [Mn1(pyrimidine)(H2O)]2+ cation, half of a [Mn2(pyrimidine)2]2+ cation, and half of a [Mn3(H2O)2]2+ cation (Figure S1 in the ).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray analysis of MnMo indicated that this compound belonged to the monoclinic structure of space group P21/n [a = 7.20778(13) Å, b = 15.7128(3) Å, c = 18.1688(3) Å, β = 95.0877(7)°, and Z = 4]. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 to R1 (wR2) = 0.0196 (0.0631) using 4365 reflections with F 2 > 2.0σ(F 2) (Table S1 in the ). The non-H atoms were anisotropically refined. The H atoms of pyrimidine and water were refined isotropically. The asymmetric unit consisted of a [Mo(CN)7]4- anion, a [Mn1(pyrimidine)(H2O)]2+ cation, half of a [Mn2(pyrimidine)2]2+ cation, and half of a [Mn3(H2O)2]2+ cation (Figure S1 in the ).

elements.content: The broadening of the XRD pattern in VMo is considered to be due to the low crystallinity derived from the lack of V2+ and [Mo(CN)7]4− from the lattice. The defects will be occupied by water molecules, resulting in the number of water molecules on VMo being higher than that of MnMo.
elements.clean_text: The broadening of the XRD pattern in VMo is considered to be due to the low crystallinity derived from the lack of V2+ and [Mo(CN)7]4- from the lattice. The defects will be occupied by water molecules, resulting in the number of water molecules on VMo being higher than that of MnMo.

elements.content:
Five batches of VMo synthesis under the same reaction conditions showed the same magnetic properties, indicating that the present VMo can be obtained reproducibly.

This M S value of VMo is closed to the expected saturation value of 5.0 μB, assuming that this compound is a ferrimagnet with antiferromagnetic interaction between VII (S = 3/2) and MoIII (S = 1/2). This difference of M S values may be due to the low crystallinity of the prepared sample.
elements.clean_text:
Five batches of VMo synthesis under the same reaction conditions showed the same magnetic properties, indicating that the present VMo can be obtained reproducibly.

This M S value of VMo is closed to the expected saturation value of 5.0 μB, assuming that this compound is a ferrimagnet with antiferromagnetic interaction between VII (S = 3/2) and MoIII (S = 1/2). This difference of M S values may be due to the low crystallinity of the prepared sample.

cln_elements.content: The value of the product of the molar magnetic susceptibility (χM) and temperature, χM T, of VMo was 3.9 cm3 K mol−1 at room temperature (Figure S3 in the ), which corresponds to the spin-only value of 4.1 cm3 K mol−1 for MoIII (S = 1/2) and 2VII (S = 3/2). Figure shows the magnetization versus temperature plots of VMo. In the field-cooled magnetization (FCM) curve at 10 Oe, spontaneous magnetization appeared at T C = 110 K. The magnetization versus external magnetic field plots at 2 K showed that the M S value was 3.0 μB, while the magnetic hysteresis loop had a coercive field (H c) of 300 Oe at 2 K (Figure b,c). The magnetic properties of MnMo, which is a sample composed of numerous single crystals, exhibited ferrimagnetism with T C = 47 K, M S = 9.0 μB, and H c = 60 Oe at 2 K. The high T C of VMo is likely due to (i) the diffuse 4d orbitals of Mo, which enable an effective superexchange interaction through the cyano groups, and (ii) the high-energy 3d orbitals of V, which lead to a good energy match with the magnetic orbital of [Mo(CN)7]4−.

metadata.title: Vanadium(II) Heptacyanomolybdate(III)-Based Magnet Exhibiting a High Curie Temperature of 110 K
